contentrichtext.text: The '''Vesta''' or '''Vestian''' [[asteroid family|'''family''' of asteroids]] is a large and prominent grouping of mostly [[V-type asteroid]]s ("vestoids") in the inner [[asteroid belt]] in the vicinity of [[4 Vesta]]. ==Characteristics== [[Image:Vesta family.png|left|thumb|350px|Location and structure of the Vesta family.]] The Vestian asteroids consist of [[4 Vesta]], the second-most-massive <!--dwarf planet Ceres is also an asteroid-->of all asteroids (mean diameter of 530 km), and many small asteroids below 10 km diameter. The brightest of these, [[1929 Kollaa]] and [[2045 Peking]], have an [[absolute magnitude]] of 12.2, which would give them a radius of about 7.5 km assuming the same high albedo as [[4 Vesta]]. The family originated from an impact on asteroid [[4 Vesta]], with the giant south-polar crater the likely impact site. The family are thought to be the source of the [[HED meteorite]]s. The Vesta family also includes a few [[J-type asteroid]]s (related to the [[v-type asteroid|V-type]]), which are thought to have come from the deeper layers of Vesta's crust, and are similar to the [[diogenite]] meteorites A HCM numerical analysis by (Zappala 1995) determined a large group of 'core' family members, whose [[proper orbital elements]] lie in the approximate ranges {| align="center" style="border:1px solid #CCC; margin-left:15px;" cellpadding="5" ! !! A search of a recent proper-element database ([http://hamilton.dm.unipi.it/cgi-bin/astdys/astibo?proper_elements:0;main AstDys]) for 96944 [[minor planet]]s in 2005 yielded 6051 objects (about 6% of the total) lying within the Vesta-family region as per the first table above. ==Interlopers== Spectroscopic analyses have shown that some of the largest Vestians are in fact interlopers. They are not of the [[V-type asteroid|V]] or [[J-type asteroid|J]] spectral class, but have similar orbital elements by coincidence. These include [[306 Unitas]], [[442 Eichsfeldia]], [[1697 Koskenniemi]], [[1781 Van Biesbroeck]], [[2024 McLaughlin]], [[2029 Binomi]], [[2086 Newell]], [[2346 Lilio]], and others.
